title:
Evaluating the Potential of Federated Learning for Maize Leaf Disease
  Prediction
authors:
Thalita Mendon\c{c}a Antico and Larissa F. Rodrigues Moreira and
  Rodrigo Moreira
abstract:
The diagnosis of diseases in food crops based on machine learning seemed
satisfactory and suitable for use on a large scale. The Convolutional Neural
Networks (CNNs) perform accurately in the disease prediction considering the
image capture of the crop leaf, being extensively enhanced in the literature.
These machine learning techniques fall short in data privacy, as they require
sharing the data in the training process with a central server, disregarding
competitive or regulatory concerns. Thus, Federated Learning (FL) aims to
support distributed training to address recognized gaps in centralized
training. As far as we know, this paper inaugurates the use and evaluation of
FL applied in maize leaf diseases. We evaluated the performance of five CNNs
trained under the distributed paradigm and measured their training time
compared to the classification performance. In addition, we consider the
suitability of distributed training considering the volume of network traffic
and the number of parameters of each CNN. Our results indicate that FL
potentially enhances data privacy in heterogeneous domains.
